natural problem: Yann and Camille go to a restaurant.  If there are 10 items on the menu, and each orders one dish, how many different combinations of meals can Yann and Camille order? (Note that they are allowed to order the same dish, and that it does matter who orders what.)
natural solution: Yann can order 10 different dishes. After he has chosen a dish, Camille can also choose 10 different dishes.
Thus there are a total of $10\cdot 10 = \boxed{100}$ different possible combinations of meals.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes n :: nat 
assumes h0 : "n = 10"
shows  "n*n = 100"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Yann and Camille go to a restaurant.  If there are 10 items on the menu, and each orders one dish, how many different combinations of meals can Yann and Camille order? (Note that they are allowed to order the same dish, and that it does matter who orders what.) The final Answer is 100
 ### Proof
 Yann can order 10 different dishes. After he has chosen a dish, Camille can also choose 10 different dishes.
 Thus there are a total of $10\cdot 10 = \boxed{100}$ different possible combinations of meals.
 *)

theorem 
fixes n :: nat 
assumes h0 : "n = 10"
shows  "n*n = 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: "What is the square of 10? The final answer is 100."

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes combinations :: nat and items :: nat
assumes h0 : "items = 10"
and h1 : "combinations = items * items"
shows  "combinations = 100"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Yann and Camille go to a restaurant.  If there are 10 items on the menu, and each orders one dish, how many different combinations of meals can Yann and Camille order? (Note that they are allowed to order the same dish, and that it does matter who orders what.) The final Answer is 100
 ### Proof
 Yann can order 10 different dishes. After he has chosen a dish, Camille can also choose 10 different dishes.

 *)

theorem
fixes combinations :: nat and items :: nat
assumes h0 : "items = 10"
and h1 : "combinations = items * items"
shows  "combinations = 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: "If there are 10 items and the number of combinations is equal to the square of the number of items, how many combinations are there? The final answer is 100."

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes items :: nat and persons :: nat
assumes h0 : "items = 10"
and h1 : "persons = 2"
shows  "(items ^ persons) = 100"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Yann and Camille go to a restaurant.  If there are 10 items on the menu, and each orders one dish, how many different combinations of meals can Yann and Camille order? (Note that they are allowed to order the same dish, and that it does matter who orders what.) The final Answer is 100
 ### Proof
 Yann can order 10 different dishes. After he has chosen a dish, Camille can also choose 10 different dishes.
 Thus there are a total of $10\cdot 10 = \boxed{100}$ different possible combinations of meals.
 *)

theorem
fixes items :: nat and persons :: nat
assumes h0 : "items = 10"
and h1 : "persons = 2"
shows  "(items ^ persons) = 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: If there are 10 items and 2 persons, what is the value when the number of items is raised to the power of the number of persons? The final answer is 100.

assumes h0 : "menuItems = 10"
and h1 : "combinations = menuItems * menuItems"
shows  "combinations = 100"

 Yann and Camille go to a restaurant.  If there are 10 items on the menu, and each orders one dish, how many different combinations of meals can Yann and Camille order? (Note that they are allowed to order the same dish, and that it does matter who orders what.) The final Answer is 100

theorem
fixes menuItems :: int and combinations :: int
assumes h0 : "menuItems = 10"
and h1 : "combinations = menuItems * menuItems"
shows  "combinations = 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: If there are 10 items on a menu and the number of possible combinations of two items is calculated as the product of the number of items with itself, how many combinations are there? The final answer is 100.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Yann_order Camille_order :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card Yann_order = 10"
and h1 : "card Camille_order = 10"
shows  "card (Yann_order \<times> Camille_order) = 100"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Yann and Camille go to a restaurant.  If there are 10 items on the menu, and each orders one dish, how many different combinations of meals can Yann and Camille order? (Note that they are allowed to order the same dish, and that it does matter who orders what.) The final Answer is 100
 ### Proof
 Yann can order 10 different dishes. After he has chosen a dish, Camille can also choose 10 different dishes.
 Thus there are a total of $10\cdot 10 = \boxed{100}$ different possible combinations of meals.
 *)

theorem
fixes Yann_order Camille_order :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card Yann_order = 10"
and h1 : "card Camille_order = 10"
shows  "card (Yann_order \<times> Camille_order) = 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Yann and Camille each have a set of 10 unique items. How many unique combinations can be made if one item is taken from Yann's set and one from Camille's set? The final answer is 100.
